awd_titl_txt: Coherent Structures and Mixing in Rotating and Stratified Flows
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a proposal to explore and model the structure of turbulence that leads to mixing in turbulent flows. The work will focus on cases of anisotropic turbulence, an area that has not been explored as much as other turbulent flows, but is of the utmost importance in engineering and in the environment. The research proposed in this work covers computations at a multitude of scales, even scales relevant to geophysical flows, allowing the results to be useful not only because of the fundamental aspect of turbulent mixing, but also due to applicability in practical situations. Our climate, agriculture, and commerce are affected by turbulence in the atmosphere and in the ocean. This work could lead to more accurate models for ocean and atmospheric flows with impact on policy, economic and infrastructure decision. The data that will be generated will become available to the scientific community through the established Johns Hopkins University Turbulence Database. In addition, graduate students will participate in this project. 

The goal of the proposed study is to investigate rotation and stratification effects and the scales at which different mixing dynamics are active in a turbulent flow. The PI proposes to use state-of-the-art direct numerical simulations (DNS) code and to run several large calculations using computational resources that are quite impressive (available through allocations from the DOE Office of Science). The proposed work aims to advance our fundamental understanding of turbulent mixing by, 1) characterizing and quantifying the instrinsic scales of coherent structures formed in canonical rotating and stratified flows using statistical measures and, 2) quantifying the relationship of the scales thus recovered to the statistics and the instrinsic scales of mixing.

por.por_cntn:
The rotation of the earth and the mostly stable stratification of the oceans and atmosphere (warmer lighter fluid lies on top of heavier denser fluid) causes these massive earth-scale systems to organize into smaller coherent structures that range in shape from tall and columnar, to flat and pancake-like. Our research was motivated by two goals related to the formation and behavior of these structures. The first was to try to understand how the shapes of these structures vary with the large scale parameters such as rate of rotation, degree of stratification and depth of fluid. And the second was how these coherent structures might affect the mechanism and degree of mixing, for example of thermal currents and salinity,  in geophysical flow systems. Mixing phenomena in the ocean and atmosphere are an important element to understanding and predicting long-term and potentially catastrophic changes in the earth's climate.

The main outcome of this work addressed the first question we posed above. Using a series of high-resolution simulations with varying rotation rate, stratification and depth of fluid, we assessed the characteristic flow scales that emerge using several different statistical measures. We found that flow domains that are much deeper than they are wide yielded the greatest departure from the nominal theoretical predictions for how the structures should vary. Indeed the deeper the flow, the harder it is to sustain arbitrarily elongated columnar structures oriented along the depth. Conversely, there was no such inhibition for structures oriented along the horizontal in shallow flow domains; these seemed to only be limited by the horizontal extent of the domain. These outcomes held true even when we accounted for possible artificial imprint of the large `domain-shaped' scales and specifically interoggated successively smaller (and presumable more independent) scales.

It is reasonably believed that flow structures may influence mixing mechanisms. The outcomes of this project then imply that for the same rotation and stratification regimes a deep flow may exhibit very different mixing mechanisms and efficiencies than do shallow flows. These are issues that motivate further fundamental research in the future.
